However, this heat treatment is a one-size-fits-all approach that doesn't distinguish between harmful and beneficial bacteria. As a result, pasteurization destroys not only pathogens like E. coli or Salmonella, but it also eliminates the naturally occurring probiotics and enzymes that are present in raw milk and support digestion and gut health.

When it comes to safety, the belief that pasteurization is the only way to ensure milk is safe is a misconception. In fact, raw milk, when sourced from healthy animals and handled properly, can be just as—if not more—safe than pasteurized milk. This is because raw milk from well-managed farms often contains natural protective factors, including immune factors from the cow and a balanced microbiome, which can help prevent harmful bacteria from taking hold. Additionally, many outbreaks linked to raw milk have actually been the result of poor handling or poor animal health, not the raw milk itself.

Nutritionally, raw milk retains its full complement of vitamins, enzymes, and beneficial bacteria. For example, enzymes like lactase and phosphatase, which aid in digestion and nutrient absorption, are destroyed during pasteurization. Raw milk also contains higher levels of certain vitamins, including B12, folate, and vitamin C, as well as bioavailable calcium that's more easily absorbed by the body.

So, in summary, raw milk is nutritionally more complete and can be just as safe—if not safer—than pasteurized milk when it's produced under proper conditions. It’s a natural, whole food that supports digestive health and provides a broader range of nutrients.
